0.text: Hypertension is blood pressure above 140/90 mmHg, major risk factor for heart disease and stroke.

1.text: Stage 1 hypertension is 130-139/80-89 mmHg, often manageable with lifestyle changes alone.

2.text: Stage 2 hypertension is 140+/90+ mmHg, typically requires medication and lifestyle changes.

3.text: Hypertensive crisis is BP above 180/120 mmHg, requiring immediate emergency medical attention.

4.text: Atherosclerosis is plaque buildup in arteries, restricting blood flow to vital organs.

5.text: Coronary artery disease develops when heart arteries become narrowed by cholesterol plaque.

6.text: Myocardial infarction occurs when coronary blockage prevents oxygen reaching heart muscle.

7.text: Heart attack symptoms include chest pressure, arm pain, shortness of breath, and sweating.

8.text: Women may have atypical heart attack symptoms including nausea, fatigue, and back pain.

9.text: Angina is chest pain from reduced heart blood flow, typically triggered by exertion or stress.

10.text: Stable angina follows predictable patterns while unstable angina occurs at rest.

11.text: Atrial fibrillation is irregular heartbeat increasing stroke risk through blood clot formation.

12.text: Heart failure occurs when heart cannot pump enough blood to meet body's metabolic needs.

13.text: Congestive heart failure causes fluid accumulation in lungs, legs, and abdomen.

14.text: ACE inhibitors treat hypertension and heart failure by reducing angiotensin II formation.

15.text: Beta-blockers slow heart rate and reduce blood pressure by blocking epinephrine effects.

16.text: Statins lower cholesterol by blocking HMG-CoA reductase enzyme in liver.

17.text: Aspirin therapy reduces heart attack risk by preventing platelet aggregation and clotting.

18.text: Cardiac catheterization visualizes coronary arteries and can open blockages with stents.

19.text: Coronary artery bypass grafting redirects blood flow around blocked coronary arteries.

20.text: Electrocardiogram records heart's electrical activity, detecting rhythm abnormalities and ischemia.

21.text: Echocardiogram uses ultrasound to visualize heart structure and assess pumping function.

22.text: Stress test evaluates heart function during exercise, revealing ischemia not apparent at rest.

23.text: LDL cholesterol below 100 mg/dL is optimal, while HDL above 60 mg/dL protects heart.

24.text: Smoking cessation dramatically reduces cardiovascular disease risk within months of quitting.

25.text: Mediterranean diet reduces heart disease risk through healthy fats and plant-based foods.

26.text: Regular aerobic exercise strengthens heart and reduces cardiovascular disease risk by 30-40%.

27.text: Stroke occurs when brain blood supply is interrupted, causing rapid brain cell death.

28.text: Ischemic stroke is caused by blood clot blocking brain artery, treated with clot-busting drugs.

29.text: Hemorrhagic stroke involves blood vessel rupture, creating pressure damaging brain tissue.

30.text: FAST acronym for stroke: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call 911.

31.text: tPA dissolves clots if given within 4.5 hours of ischemic stroke symptom onset.

32.text: Deep vein thrombosis forms blood clots in deep leg veins, risking pulmonary embolism.

33.text: Pulmonary embolism occurs when blood clot travels to lungs, potentially life-threatening.

34.text: Peripheral artery disease causes leg pain with walking from arterial narrowing.

35.text: Aortic aneurysm is dangerous artery bulging that can rupture, causing internal bleeding.

36.text: Pacemaker regulates heart rhythm by delivering electrical impulses when heart beats too slowly.

37.text: Implantable defibrillator detects and corrects dangerous arrhythmias automatically.

38.text: Cardiac rehabilitation combines exercise, education, and support improving heart disease outcomes.

39.text: Blood pressure control is single most important intervention for preventing stroke.

40.text: Type 1 diabetes is autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing pancreatic beta cells.

41.text: Type 2 diabetes involves insulin resistance where body cells don't respond properly to insulin.

42.text: Prediabetes is blood glucose 100-125 mg/dL fasting, indicating high diabetes risk.

43.text: Gestational diabetes develops during pregnancy, increasing risks for mother and baby.

44.text: Hemoglobin A1C measures average blood glucose over previous 2-3 months.

45.text: A1C target for most diabetics is below 7% to prevent long-term complications.

46.text: Fasting glucose above 126 mg/dL on two occasions confirms diabetes diagnosis.

47.text: Insulin regulates blood sugar by facilitating glucose uptake into body cells.

48.text: Metformin is first-line type 2 diabetes medication, reducing liver glucose production.

49.text: GLP-1 agonists improve glucose control, promote weight loss, and reduce cardiovascular events.

50.text: SGLT2 inhibitors increase urinary glucose excretion, lowering blood sugar and protecting heart.

51.text: Continuous glucose monitors provide real-time glucose readings, improving diabetes management.

52.text: Diabetic ketoacidosis is life-threatening type 1 complication requiring emergency treatment.

53.text: Hypoglycemia below 70 mg/dL causes shakiness, confusion, and can lead to unconsciousness.

54.text: Diabetic neuropathy damages nerves causing pain, numbness, especially in feet.

55.text: Diabetic retinopathy damages retinal blood vessels, leading to vision loss if untreated.

56.text: Diabetic nephropathy causes kidney damage, potentially progressing to kidney failure.

57.text: Diabetes increases cardiovascular disease risk 2-4 times through accelerated atherosclerosis.

58.text: Foot care is critical for diabetics to prevent ulcers, infections, and amputations.

59.text: Carbohydrate counting helps diabetics match insulin doses to food intake for better control.

60.text: Regular exercise improves insulin sensitivity and glucose control in both diabetes types.

61.text: Weight loss of 5-10% significantly improves type 2 diabetes control and may achieve remission.

62.text: Hypothyroidism slows metabolism, causing fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance.

63.text: Hyperthyroidism accelerates metabolism, causing weight loss, heat intolerance, and anxiety.

64.text: TSH test screens thyroid function, elevated in hypothyroidism, suppressed in hyperthyroidism.

65.text: Levothyroxine replaces thyroid hormone in hypothyroidism, taken daily on empty stomach.

66.text: Hashimoto's thyroiditis is autoimmune hypothyroidism, most common thyroid dysfunction cause.

67.text: Graves' disease is autoimmune hyperthyroidism, often causing bulging eyes.

68.text: Cushing's syndrome results from excess cortisol, causing weight gain and hypertension.

69.text: Addison's disease involves insufficient cortisol, causing fatigue and low blood pressure.

70.text: Polycystic ovary syndrome causes hormonal imbalance, irregular periods, and infertility.

71.text: Growth hormone deficiency in children impairs growth, requiring hormone replacement therapy.

72.text: Metabolic syndrome combines obesity, hypertension, high triglycerides, and insulin resistance.

73.text: Thyroid nodules are common, usually benign, but require evaluation to exclude cancer.

74.text: Radioactive iodine treats hyperthyroidism by selectively destroying overactive thyroid tissue.

75.text: Adrenal insufficiency requires immediate steroid replacement during illness to prevent crisis.

76.text: Diabetes management requires monitoring blood glucose, medications, diet, and exercise.

77.text: Bariatric surgery can induce type 2 diabetes remission through metabolic changes.

78.text: Insulin pump delivers continuous insulin, closely mimicking normal pancreatic function.

79.text: Glycemic index ranks carbohydrates by blood sugar impact, guiding diabetic food choices.

80.text: Asthma is chronic airway inflammation causing reversible bronchoconstriction and wheezing.

81.text: Asthma affects 25 million Americans, leading chronic disease in children.

82.text: Asthma triggers include allergens, exercise, cold air, smoke, and viral infections.

83.text: Quick-relief bronchodilators rapidly open airways during asthma attacks.

84.text: Inhaled corticosteroids control asthma inflammation long-term, reducing attack frequency.

85.text: Peak flow meter measures airflow obstruction, helping monitor asthma control.

86.text: COPD combines chronic bronchitis and emphysema, causing progressive breathing difficulty.

87.text: Smoking causes 80-90% of COPD cases through chronic airway irritation and damage.

88.text: COPD symptoms include chronic cough, sputum production, and progressive shortness of breath.

89.text: Spirometry diagnoses COPD by measuring airflow obstruction severity through FEV1/FVC ratio.

90.text: Smoking cessation is most important COPD intervention, significantly slowing disease progression.

91.text: Bronchodilators relieve COPD symptoms by relaxing airway muscles and improving breathing.

92.text: Pulmonary rehabilitation combines exercise, education, and support improving COPD outcomes.

93.text: Supplemental oxygen therapy increases survival in COPD patients with chronic hypoxemia.

94.text: Pneumonia inflames lung air sacs, filling them with fluid impairing gas exchange.

95.text: Bacterial pneumonia often follows viral respiratory infection, causing productive cough and fever.

96.text: Antibiotic choice for pneumonia depends on likely pathogens, severity, and resistance patterns.

97.text: Pneumococcal vaccine prevents Streptococcus pneumoniae, leading bacterial pneumonia cause.

98.text: Tuberculosis is bacterial infection primarily affecting lungs, requiring prolonged antibiotic treatment.

99.text: TB symptoms include chronic cough, night sweats, weight loss, and blood-tinged sputum.

100.text: Active TB requires 6-9 months of multiple antibiotics to prevent resistance and ensure cure.

101.text: Pulmonary embolism blocks pulmonary arteries with blood clots, causing sudden dyspnea.

102.text: Lung cancer is leading cancer killer, with smoking responsible for 85% of cases.

103.text: Low-dose CT screening reduces lung cancer mortality in high-risk current and former smokers.

104.text: Bronchitis inflames bronchial tubes, causing cough and mucus production, often viral.

105.text: Sleep apnea causes repeated breathing interruptions during sleep, increasing cardiovascular risk.

106.text: CPAP therapy maintains positive airway pressure, preventing airway collapse in sleep apnea.

107.text: Influenza causes seasonal respiratory illness, preventable with annual vaccination.

108.text: COVID-19 vaccines dramatically reduce severe disease, hospitalization, and death risk.

109.text: Inhaler technique is critical for asthma and COPD control, requires proper patient education.

110.text: Alzheimer's disease progressively destroys memory through brain cell death and protein accumulation.

111.text: Beta-amyloid plaques and tau tangles are Alzheimer's hallmark brain pathological changes.

112.text: Alzheimer's affects 6.7 million Americans aged 65+, projected to triple by 2060.

113.text: Early Alzheimer's symptoms include memory loss, confusion, and difficulty with familiar tasks.

114.text: Cholinesterase inhibitors modestly improve Alzheimer's cognitive symptoms and daily function.

115.text: Memantine regulates glutamate activity in moderate-to-severe Alzheimer's disease.

116.text: Parkinson's disease causes dopamine deficiency in brain, producing motor symptoms.

117.text: Parkinson's classic triad: resting tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia (slow movement).

118.text: Levodopa converts to dopamine in brain, providing most effective Parkinson's symptom relief.

119.text: Deep brain stimulation electrically modulates brain circuits, reducing Parkinson's motor symptoms.

120.text: Multiple sclerosis involves autoimmune attack on nerve myelin, disrupting signal transmission.

121.text: MS symptoms vary widely: weakness, numbness, vision problems, balance issues, cognitive changes.

122.text: Disease-modifying therapies reduce MS relapses and slow disability progression.

123.text: Epilepsy causes recurrent seizures from abnormal brain electrical activity.

124.text: Antiepileptic drugs control 70% of epilepsy, working through various brain mechanisms.

125.text: Status epilepticus is prolonged seizure requiring emergency treatment to prevent brain damage.

126.text: Stroke symptoms require immediate emergency care to minimize permanent brain damage.

127.text: TIA (transient ischemic attack) causes temporary stroke-like symptoms, warning of high stroke risk.

128.text: Migraine causes severe headache with nausea and light sensitivity, often disabling.

129.text: Triptans are effective migraine-specific medications, constricting blood vessels and blocking pain.

130.text: Tension headache is most common headache type, caused by muscle tension and stress.

131.text: Dementia is general term for cognitive decline severe enough to interfere with daily life.

132.text: Vascular dementia results from reduced blood flow to brain, often following strokes.

133.text: Peripheral neuropathy damages peripheral nerves, causing numbness, tingling, and pain in extremities.

134.text: Carpal tunnel syndrome causes hand numbness from median nerve compression in wrist.

135.text: Sciatica causes leg pain from sciatic nerve compression, often from herniated disc.

136.text: Concussion is mild traumatic brain injury requiring rest and gradual return to activity.

137.text: Meningitis inflames brain and spinal cord membranes, requiring urgent medical treatment.

138.text: Brain imaging with CT or MRI helps diagnose stroke, tumors, and structural abnormalities.

139.text: Cognitive behavioral therapy is effective treatment for many neurological and psychiatric conditions.

140.text: Cancer develops when cells acquire mutations enabling uncontrolled growth and spread.

141.text: Breast cancer is most common cancer in women, with 1 in 8 lifetime risk.

142.text: Mammography screening detects breast cancer early when treatment is most effective.

143.text: BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations greatly increase breast and ovarian cancer risk.

144.text: Lung cancer is leading cancer killer, strongly associated with cigarette smoking.

145.text: Lung cancer screening with low-dose CT reduces mortality in high-risk smokers.

146.text: Colorectal cancer develops from polyps over years, making screening highly effective.

147.text: Colonoscopy finds and removes precancerous polyps, preventing colorectal cancer development.

148.text: Prostate cancer is most common cancer in men, typically slow-growing.

149.text: PSA screening for prostate cancer is controversial, requiring informed individual decisions.

150.text: Skin cancer is most common cancer type, with basal cell carcinoma most frequent.

151.text: Melanoma is most dangerous skin cancer, potentially deadly but curable when caught early.

152.text: ABCDE rule identifies melanoma: Asymmetry, Border, Color, Diameter, Evolution.

153.text: Sun protection through sunscreen, protective clothing reduces skin cancer risk significantly.

154.text: Leukemia is cancer of blood-forming tissues, causing abnormal white blood cell production.

155.text: Lymphoma is cancer of lymphatic system, divided into Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin types.

156.text: Hodgkin lymphoma is highly curable with chemotherapy and radiation, even in advanced stages.

157.text: Pancreatic cancer has poor prognosis due to late detection and aggressive biology.

158.text: Ovarian cancer often presents with vague symptoms, frequently diagnosed at advanced stage.

159.text: Cervical cancer is preventable through HPV vaccination and regular Pap test screening.

160.text: HPV causes most cervical cancers, with types 16 and 18 most oncogenic.

161.text: Chemotherapy kills rapidly dividing cells, affecting cancer and causing side effects.

162.text: Radiation therapy damages cancer cell DNA, causing death after accumulation of damage.

163.text: Immunotherapy harnesses immune system to fight cancer, producing durable responses.

164.text: Targeted therapy exploits specific cancer cell vulnerabilities with fewer side effects.

165.text: Bone marrow transplant can cure some leukemias by replacing cancerous cells.

166.text: Cancer staging guides treatment, ranging from localized disease to distant metastases.

167.text: Palliative care improves quality of life for cancer patients through symptom management.

168.text: Cancer survivors require long-term follow-up for recurrence detection and late effects.

169.text: Clinical trials test new cancer treatments, offering access to cutting-edge therapies.

170.text: Influenza virus causes seasonal respiratory illness, preventable with annual vaccination.

171.text: Flu complications include pneumonia, myocarditis, and can be life-threatening.

172.text: Antiviral medications like oseltamivir reduce flu duration if started within 48 hours.

173.text: COVID-19 is caused by SARS-CoV-2 virus, spreading primarily through respiratory droplets.

174.text: COVID-19 vaccines dramatically reduce infection severity, hospitalization, and death.

175.text: Long COVID causes persistent symptoms including fatigue, brain fog, lasting months.

176.text: HIV attacks immune system CD4 cells, progressively weakening body's defenses.

177.text: AIDS is advanced HIV disease with CD4 count below 200 or opportunistic infections.

178.text: Antiretroviral therapy suppresses HIV replication, preventing AIDS and transmission.

179.text: Undetectable HIV viral load means virus cannot be transmitted sexually (U=U).

180.text: Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) prevents HIV acquisition in high-risk individuals.

181.text: Hepatitis B transmits through blood and body fluids, vaccine-preventable, can become chronic.

182.text: Chronic hepatitis B can cause cirrhosis and liver cancer, treatable with antivirals.

183.text: Hepatitis C transmits through blood, often chronic, now curable with direct-acting antivirals.

184.text: Tuberculosis spreads through airborne droplets, requiring prolonged multi-drug treatment.

185.text: Malaria is transmitted by mosquitoes, causing 400,000 deaths annually, mostly in Africa.

186.text: Lyme disease is transmitted by deer ticks, causing rash and systemic symptoms.

187.text: Sexually transmitted infections are rising, requiring screening and treatment to prevent complications.

188.text: Chlamydia and gonorrhea are curable but often asymptomatic, causing infertility if untreated.

189.text: Syphilis progresses through stages if untreated, potentially causing severe complications.

190.text: HPV vaccine prevents genital warts and cancers, most effective before sexual debut.

191.text: Urinary tract infections are common in women, causing dysuria, frequency, and urgency.

192.text: Antibiotic resistance is growing threat, necessitating appropriate antibiotic use.

193.text: C. difficile colitis causes severe diarrhea after antibiotics disrupt normal gut flora.

194.text: MRSA is antibiotic-resistant staph causing difficult-to-treat skin and invasive infections.

195.text: Sepsis is dysregulated immune response to infection causing organ dysfunction.

196.text: Early sepsis recognition and treatment with antibiotics and fluids improves survival.

197.text: Vaccination has eliminated or controlled many infectious diseases, saving millions of lives.

198.text: Hand hygiene is single most important infection prevention measure.

199.text: Respiratory etiquette including covering coughs reduces respiratory infection transmission.

200.text: Major depression affects 21 million US adults, causing persistent sadness and loss of interest.

201.text: Depression symptoms include depressed mood, anhedonia, sleep changes, and guilt.

202.text: SSRIs are first-line antidepressants with favorable side effect profile.

203.text: Cognitive behavioral therapy changes negative thought patterns causing depression.

204.text: Electroconvulsive therapy induces controlled seizure, highly effective for severe depression.

205.text: Depression increases heart disease, stroke, and dementia risk through multiple pathways.

206.text: Anxiety disorders affect 40 million Americans, causing excessive worry interfering with life.

207.text: Generalized anxiety disorder involves persistent excessive worry about multiple life areas.

208.text: Panic disorder causes recurrent unexpected panic attacks with intense fear.

209.text: Social anxiety disorder involves intense fear of social situations and negative evaluation.

210.text: Exposure therapy systematically confronts feared situations, highly effective for anxiety.

211.text: Bipolar disorder causes extreme mood swings between manic highs and depressive lows.

212.text: Mood stabilizers like lithium prevent bipolar mood episodes and reduce suicide risk.

213.text: Schizophrenia affects thinking and perception, often involving delusions and hallucinations.

214.text: Antipsychotic medications treat schizophrenia by modulating dopamine and other neurotransmitters.

215.text: PTSD develops after trauma exposure, causing intrusive memories and hyperarousal.

216.text: Trauma-focused therapies like prolonged exposure are first-line PTSD treatments.

217.text: OCD involves unwanted intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors (compulsions).

218.text: Exposure and response prevention is gold-standard OCD treatment.

219.text: ADHD affects 8% of children and 4% of adults, characterized by inattention and impulsivity.

220.text: Stimulant medications like methylphenidate are first-line ADHD treatment.

221.text: Eating disorders include anorexia, bulimia, and binge eating disorder.

222.text: Anorexia nervosa involves restrictive eating and distorted body image.

223.text: Eating disorders have highest mortality of psychiatric conditions.

224.text: Substance use disorders involve compulsive drug use despite harmful consequences.

225.text: Medication-assisted treatment combines therapy with medications for addiction.

226.text: Mental health stigma prevents many from seeking help though conditions are treatable.

227.text: Suicide is preventable, with warning signs including hopelessness and withdrawal.

228.text: Crisis resources like 988 Suicide Lifeline provide immediate mental health support.

229.text: Psychotherapy treats mental health conditions through evidence-based talk therapy approaches.

230.text: GERD occurs when stomach acid flows back into esophagus, irritating its lining.

231.text: Proton pump inhibitors are most effective GERD medications, healing esophagitis.

232.text: Inflammatory bowel disease includes Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

233.text: Celiac disease is autoimmune reaction to gluten, requiring strict gluten-free diet.

234.text: Cirrhosis is end-stage liver scarring from chronic damage, leading to liver failure.

235.text: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease affects 25% of population, linked to obesity.

236.text: Chronic kidney disease is progressive kidney function loss over months to years.

237.text: Diabetes and hypertension cause most chronic kidney disease cases.

238.text: Dialysis removes waste and excess fluid when kidneys fail.

239.text: Kidney transplant is preferred treatment for kidney failure, offering better outcomes than dialysis.

240.text: Acute kidney injury is sudden kidney failure, often reversible if treated promptly.

241.text: Urinary tract infections cause dysuria and frequency, treated with antibiotics.

242.text: Kidney stones form from mineral crystallization, causing severe pain when passing.

243.text: Osteoarthritis is cartilage breakdown from wear and tear, causing joint pain and stiffness.

244.text: Rheumatoid arthritis is autoimmune joint inflammation, treated with disease-modifying drugs.

245.text: Osteoporosis weakens bones through decreased density, dramatically increasing fracture risk.

246.text: DEXA scan measures bone density, diagnosing osteoporosis and assessing fracture risk.

247.text: Bisphosphonates are first-line osteoporosis drugs, reducing fracture risk.

248.text: Gout causes sudden severe joint pain from uric acid crystal deposition.

249.text: Back pain affects 80% of people during lifetime, usually self-limiting.

250.text: Herniated disc causes pain when disc material compresses nerve root.

251.text: Physical therapy helps restore movement and function after musculoskeletal injury.

252.text: Hip replacement surgery treats severe arthritis and joint damage.

253.text: Knee replacement surgery provides pain relief and improved function for severe arthritis.

254.text: Fibromyalgia causes widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and sleep problems.

255.text: Carpal tunnel syndrome causes hand numbness from median nerve compression.

256.text: Rotator cuff tears cause shoulder pain and weakness, common in older adults.

257.text: Stress fractures result from repetitive force, common in runners and athletes.

258.text: Tendinitis is inflammation of tendon, causing pain and limited movement.

259.text: Plantar fasciitis causes heel pain from inflammation of foot arch ligament.

260.text: Pregnancy involves 40 weeks of fetal development divided into three trimesters.

261.text: Prenatal care includes regular checkups monitoring mother and baby's health.

262.text: Folic acid supplementation before conception prevents neural tube defects.

263.text: Gestational diabetes screening occurs at 24-28 weeks, requiring glucose control.

264.text: Preeclampsia causes hypertension and organ dysfunction after 20 weeks.

265.text: Breastfeeding provides optimal infant nutrition and maternal health benefits.

266.text: Postpartum depression affects 1 in 7 women, requiring recognition and treatment.

267.text: Contraception options include hormonal methods, IUDs, barrier methods, and sterilization.

268.text: Menopause transition brings hormonal changes causing hot flashes and bone loss.

269.text: Cervical cancer screening with Pap tests prevents cancer through early detection.

270.text: Childhood vaccinations protect against 14 serious diseases following CDC schedule.

271.text: Vaccine safety is extensively studied, with benefits far outweighing minimal risks.

272.text: Well-child visits monitor growth, development, and provide anticipatory guidance.

273.text: Sudden infant death syndrome risk reduced by back sleeping and safe environment.

274.text: Autism spectrum disorder varies widely, requiring individualized interventions.

275.text: ADHD in children managed with medication, behavioral therapy, and school support.

276.text: Childhood obesity prevention includes healthy eating, activity, and limiting screens.

277.text: Developmental screening identifies delays enabling early intervention.

278.text: Regular exercise reduces risk of chronic diseases and improves mental health.

279.text: Balanced diet supports overall health and disease prevention.

280.text: Smoking cessation dramatically reduces risk of cancer, heart disease, and stroke.

281.text: Adequate sleep 7-9 hours nightly is essential for physical and mental health.

282.text: Stress management through meditation and exercise improves health outcomes.

283.text: Preventive care includes regular health screenings and vaccinations.

284.text: Blood pressure should be checked at least every 2 years starting at age 18.

285.text: Cholesterol screening recommended starting at age 35 for men, 45 for women.

286.text: Colorectal cancer screening should begin at age 45 for average-risk individuals.

287.text: Mammography screening for breast cancer typically begins at age 40-50.

288.text: Bone density screening for osteoporosis recommended for women at age 65.

289.text: Annual flu vaccination recommended for everyone 6 months and older.

290.text: Healthy lifestyle habits prevent up to 80% of premature heart disease and stroke.

291.text: Regular primary care visits enable early disease detection and management.

292.text: Health insurance coverage improves access to preventive and treatment services.

293.text: Advance care planning documents healthcare preferences for future decision-making.

294.text: Living will specifies end-of-life medical treatment preferences.

295.text: Healthcare proxy designates someone to make medical decisions if unable.

296.text: Telemedicine provides healthcare remotely using technology, improving access.

297.text: Electronic health records store patient information digitally, improving care coordination.

298.text: Patient privacy is protected by HIPAA regulations in healthcare settings.

299.text: Informed consent ensures patients understand treatment risks and benefits before proceeding.
